DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents a complication resulting from a pancreatic surgical procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known._A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery._Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.:A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Concepts.definition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: Complication; any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of (or because of) another disease.

Concepts.definition: Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, Toronto, ON

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a group of independent but interrelated elements comprising a unified whole._Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A state of acute circulatory failure characterized by persistent arterial hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation or by tissue hypoperfusion unexplained by other causes.

Concepts.definition: A state of acute circulatory failure characterized by persistent arterial hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation or by tissue hypoperfusion unexplained by other causes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A state of profound unconsciousness associated with markedly depressed cerebral activity for a time period of greater than 24 hours.
Inflammation of the veins associated with the presence of a thrombus.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the veins associated with the presence of a thrombus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The sudden cessation of cardiac activity in an individual that requires cardiopulmonary resuscitation to restore consciousness or life.
Any part of the anatomy, other than the incision, which was opened or manipulated during an operation.: An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

Concepts.definition: Any part of the anatomy, other than the incision, which was opened or manipulated during an operation.
An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sudden loss of neurological function secondary to hemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event.

Concepts.definition: A sudden loss of neurological function secondary to hemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Occurring during the course of a surgical procedure.: The cessation of life.

Concepts.definition: Occurring during the course of a surgical procedure.
The cessation of life.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An incision that involves deep soft tissues.: An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

Concepts.definition: An incision that involves deep soft tissues.
An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Graft or Prosthesis or Flap Failure

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Graft or Prosthesis or Flap Failure
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The failure of a tissue graft, prothesis or flap.

PermissibleValues.value: Death - <90 days, or during index hospital admission
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Death Less than 90 Days or During Index Hospital Admission

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Death Less than 90 Days or During Index Hospital Admission
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The cessation of life during the original hospital admission or within 90 days of being admitted.
Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.: Surgical removal of the pancreas. (Dorland, 28th ed): The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
Surgical removal of part or all of the pancreas.
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A blood clot in a deep vein, predominantly in the lower extremity, but may include the pelvis or upper extremity.

Concepts.definition: A blood clot in a deep vein, predominantly in the lower extremity, but may include the pelvis or upper extremity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of pathogenic microorganisms in the blood stream causing a rapidly progressing systemic reaction that may lead to shock. Symptoms include fever, chills, tachycardia, and increased respiratory rate. It is a medical emergency that requires urgent medical attention.

Concepts.definition: The presence of pathogenic microorganisms in the blood stream causing a rapidly progressing systemic reaction that may lead to shock. Symptoms include fever, chills, tachycardia, and increased respiratory rate. It is a medical emergency that requires urgent medical attention.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within the abdomen.: Any laboratory procedure for growing microorganisms.: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: Within the abdomen.
Any laboratory procedure for growing microorganisms.
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The facilitation of breathing using a ventilator for more than 48 hours.

Within the abdomen.: Any laboratory procedure for growing microorganisms.: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.definition: Within the abdomen.
Any laboratory procedure for growing microorganisms.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Leakage of bile due to breakdown of a biliary anastomosis.

Concepts.definition: Leakage of bile due to breakdown of a biliary anastomosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Leakage due to breakdown of a gastrointestinal anastomosis.

Concepts.definition: Leakage due to breakdown of a gastrointestinal anastomosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Leakage due to breakdown of a pancreatic anastomosis.

Concepts.definition: Leakage due to breakdown of a pancreatic anastomosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The inability to return to a standard diet by the end of the first postoperative week and includes prolonged nasogastric intubation of the patient.
Leakage of bile into the abdominal cavity as a result of injury to the bile duct.

Blockage in the biliary tract that carries bile from the liver to the gallbladder and small intestine.  Causes include gallstones, biliary tract strictures and inflammation, pancreatitis, cirrhosis, lymph node enlargement, and bile duct and pancreas neoplasms.

Concepts.definition: Blockage in the biliary tract that carries bile from the liver to the gallbladder and small intestine.  Causes include gallstones, biliary tract strictures and inflammation, pancreatitis, cirrhosis, lymph node enlargement, and bile duct and pancreas neoplasms.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A liver that is not adequately performing its function.
Splitting of the sutured margins of a surgical wound. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, obesity, and advanced age.

Concepts.definition: Splitting of the sutured margins of a surgical wound. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, obesity, and advanced age.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute, acute and chronic, or chronic inflammation focally or diffusely affecting the lung parenchyma, due to infections (viruses, fungi, mycoplasma, or bacteria), treatment (e.g. radiation), or exposure (inhalation) to chemicals. Symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, fevers, chills, chest pain, headache, sweating, and weakness.

Concepts.definition: An acute, acute and chronic, or chronic inflammation focally or diffusely affecting the lung parenchyma, due to infections (viruses, fungi, mycoplasma, or bacteria), treatment (e.g. radiation), or exposure (inhalation) to chemicals. Symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, fevers, chills, chest pain, headache, sweating, and weakness.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The insertion of a cannula or tube into a hollow body organ that is not planned.
The obstruction of the pulmonary artery or one of its branches by an embolus, sometimes associated with infarction of the lung.

Concepts.definition: The obstruction of the pulmonary artery or one of its branches by an embolus, sometimes associated with infarction of the lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sudden and sustained deterioration of the kidney function characterized by decreased glomerular filtration rate, increased serum creatinine or oliguria.

Concepts.definition: Sudden and sustained deterioration of the kidney function characterized by decreased glomerular filtration rate, increased serum creatinine or oliguria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bacterial infectious process affecting any part of the urinary tract, most commonly the bladder and the urethra. Symptoms include urinary urgency and frequency, burning sensation during urination, lower abdominal discomfort, and cloudy urine.

Concepts.definition: A bacterial infectious process affecting any part of the urinary tract, most commonly the bladder and the urethra. Symptoms include urinary urgency and frequency, burning sensation during urination, lower abdominal discomfort, and cloudy urine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sensory or motor loss of peripheral nerve function due to a traumatic event. (ACC)

Concepts.definition: Sensory or motor loss of peripheral nerve function due to a traumatic event. (ACC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A usually reversible condition characterized by the acute and sudden development of confusion, illusions, movement changes, inattentiveness, agitation, and hallucinations. Causes include drug abuse, poisoning, infectious processes, and fluid and electrolyte imbalance.

Concepts.definition: A usually reversible condition characterized by the acute and sudden development of confusion, illusions, movement changes, inattentiveness, agitation, and hallucinations. Causes include drug abuse, poisoning, infectious processes, and fluid and electrolyte imbalance.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and edema. Signs and symptoms include shortness of breath, pitting edema, enlarged tender liver, engorged neck veins, and pulmonary rales.

Concepts.definition: Failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and edema. Signs and symptoms include shortness of breath, pitting edema, enlarged tender liver, engorged neck veins, and pulmonary rales.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any variation from the normal rate or rhythm (which may include the origin of the impulse and/or its subsequent propagation) in the heart.

Concepts.definition: Any variation from the normal rate or rhythm (which may include the origin of the impulse and/or its subsequent propagation) in the heart.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

Concepts.definition: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An incision that involves only the skin or subcutaneous tissue.: An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

Concepts.definition: An incision that involves only the skin or subcutaneous tissue.
An infection that occurs at a surgical site within 30 days after an operation.

Concepts.definition: A group of independent but interrelated elements comprising a unified whole.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
